captions.text: If the mountain won't come to Muhammad,

then Muhammad must go to the 
mountain. It's obvious.

Actually I have no idea what 
that means, never did.
Have you heard the saying,
"Faith moves mountains"?
Well, since I'm not a man of much faith,

I figured this thing with 
mountains was not for me.

It's true that I always believed
in metaphors of life.

And naturally, you've seen how life can 
be explained with metaphors, right?

They say that
"Life is like a box of chocolates,"
or like a mirror,
or a voyage by train.

Today I'd like to share with you 
my personal metaphor for life

that I found in an activity 
for which I'm really passionate:
climbing mountains.
Years ago, during a trip to Mendoza,
I met Mount Aconcagua,
which is, outside of the Himalayas in Asia,
the tallest mountain in the world.
It was love at first sight.

In that moment I said to myself, 
"Some day I need to be there, at the top."
But there was one small glitch--

I knew absolutely nothing 
about mountain climbing!

So I began to ask questions 
and find out more,

and they explained to me that you 
don't really have to be a great athlete,
but that you do need great willpower.
So I began to join treks and expeditions,

and with time I realized how much 
the mountain had to teach me,
and how very much I had to learn.

Through this contact with nature 
I learned, for example,
that borders are man's invention.

That the environment 
doesn't demand respect,

but we have to respect it
for our own good.

That the Earth doesn't need us, 
but we need it.

That breathing connects us 
to the universe.

That we can return again and again, 
and the mountain remains the same,
while we are always different.
By going out on expeditions, with others,

I learned that in extreme circumstances,
we all show our true essence.

That we can follow a guide, but it is 
also good to learn to guide ourselves.

That we can share very profound moments 
with others,
even if we never see them again.
That alone we may arrive quicker,
but with others we can go farther.

That at times we can make 
incredible efforts,

find strength that we 
didn't even know we had,
only to help others.

Because I went out alone, 
on several occasions,

I learned the importance 
of finding one's rhythm,

and how solitude is an opportunity 
to get to know yourself.

That it is vital that we learn to listen to 
our bodies, and conserve energy,

That one can only carry the weight 
supported by one's own back.

That there are well-marked paths, yet
it is good, at times, to follow new ones.

By being lost in the mountains, 
even on the verge of death,

I learned that many big problems 
often come from bad, small decisions.

That in extreme situations, 
money is worthless.

That the most direct 
and the simplest of paths
are rarely one and the same.

That getting lost is easy, which is why 
you need to learn when to stop.

That continuing on when injured 
is dangerous, but possible.

By failing on some attempts 
to reach the summit,

I knew that summiting
is never guaranteed,
so learning to enjoy the journey is key.

That learning to adapt 
to change is not optional.

That no real-life problem 
can be solved in a book.

That sometimes the only step we 
know we can take is the next.
That many will tell us of the path ahead,
only a few can offer their advice on it,
but only you can traverse it.

By reaching the summits
of many mountains,

I learned that success lies 
not in reaching the top,
but in making it back down.

That sometimes we can't see our goal 
until we are very close to it.

That practice and dedication improve 
our chances for success.

That depending on the size of the rocks, 
we can avoid them,
step on them, climb them,

sit on them, gather them, 
or simply...contemplate them.

That sometimes we have
to try many times,
but the important thing is not to give up.
In January, 2013, I reached my final goal.

I thought it would be the end 
of my mountain-climbing career.

But in that moment 
I realized I had just begun.
And there I learned another lesson:

That upon each return 
we begin a new journey.

Reinhold Messner, the father of 
modern mountaineering, said:

"In the solitude of a mountain,
the worst is not the cold,
the altitude, but being alone."

I found mountain climbing to be 
a great metaphor for life,

and today I invite you 
to discover your own.
What are your personal metaphors?
Where are your mountains?
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: Lo que Mahoma aprendió en la montaña: Federico Pacheco at TEDxAvCorrientes 2013
